awd_titl_txt: CRII: CHS: Restoring Justice: New Designs for Moderating Social Media Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates how to address harassment and abuse in social media. Current approaches to moderation of social media either remove content or ban users. However, neither of these approaches give perpetrators the opportunity to be held accountable and to repair harm, nor do they enable communities to address systemic problems.  This project lays the intellectual groundwork to design moderation of online spaces informed by a model of justice that focuses on repairing harm, a model called restorative justice. The project will investigate the potential of technology to support restorative justice approaches.  This research will create structures for repairing online harm and sets the stage for the design of online spaces where everyone can participate equally and benefit from the full potential of technology.

This project will investigate potential roles of technology to support restorative justice practices in moderating social media platforms. The research invokes a situationally appropriate research methodology of participatory design, in order to generate new understandings of online community members’ needs and requirements. A new social media prototype will be designed to address these needs through experience, interaction, and computing. Intellectual merit is expected through (1) a qualitative study that generates data as the basis for a model of social media moderation based on principles of restorative justice; and (2) a prototype platform for moderation on Twitter based on applying these principles in conjunction with human-computer interaction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Through this work, we have investigated the integration of restorative justice principles into the moderation systems of social media platforms. Our primary goal was to explore and enhance how digital environments can support victims of online harm through justice mechanisms that prioritize healing and restoration over punitive measures.

 

Objectives and Activities:

The project was structured around two main objectives: first, to understand different stakeholders’ perceptions of justice and their responses to restorative justice approaches; and second, to co-design and evaluate digital prototypes that incorporate these approaches into the ways that we address online harm after it has occurred.

 

In the first year, we conducted semi-structured interviews with various stakeholders, including restorative justice practitioners, online moderators, survivors of online harm, and those who had caused harm online. These interviews helped us gain a deeper understanding of what survivors of online harm need, in addition to gathering diverse perspectives on justice and assessing the receptivity to restorative methods.

 

The second year focused on the design of a digital tool, SnuggleSense, which assists survivors of online harm in making sense of their experiences and planning their processes for healing and repair. This tool was inspired by the restorative justice pre-conferencing methods and was designed based on the needs identified during the initial interviews.

 

Major Findings and Accomplishments:

Our research highlighted five primary needs of online harm survivors: sensemaking, support and validation, safety, retribution, and transformation. Based on these needs, SnuggleSense was developed to empower survivors by offering a structured yet flexible framework to articulate the harm that they had experienced and plan their actions for recovery.

 

A key outcome of this project was the realization that current social media moderation practices, which often focus solely on content removal, are insufficient for addressing the complex needs of harm survivors. Our findings advocate for a more holistic approach that includes both online and offline stakeholders in the support network of survivors.

 

The effectiveness of SnuggleSense was evaluated through a comparative study between guided and unguided sensemaking processes. Results indicated that participants using SnuggleSense exhibited a stronger focus on healing and restoration rather than on punishing offenders. This shift underscores the potential of restorative justice to promote more empathetic and supportive online communities.

 

Broader Impacts:

The project has significantly contributed to the human-computer interaction (HCI) and online community safety fields by illustrating the viability of restorative justice in digital spaces. This work has encouraged a shift from viewing online harm solely as a content issue to understanding it as a relational and community issue.

 

Moreover, our findings have been shared extensively within academic and professional communities, raising awareness and sparking discussions about alternative harm reduction strategies. Workshops and presentations at conferences have helped disseminate our research outcomes to broader audiences, including stakeholders in policy-making and tech industry.

 

Conclusion:

The project has laid a foundation for the integration of restorative justice principles into online harm resolution. The development of SnuggleSense and the insights gained from our research not only enhance academic understanding but also offer practical tools and strategies for making online environments safer and more supportive.
